body:
Significant penalties can be imposed on employers who breach the GDPR, including fines of up to 20 million euros or 4% of a company’s turnover (whichever is larger). This is a huge increase from the previous £500,000 fines imposed by the Data Protection Act in the UK.

A financial penalty is seen as a last resort, so other penalties such as corrective orders can be issued.

In other cases businesses in breach of GDPR can be ordered to suspend data processing and/or erase the personal data altogether. 

In the UK the ICO publishes information about actions they have taken with organisations that have not complied with the act. There have been 110 actions in the last year alone, with 58 of these being monetary fines totalling over £5.5m.
title: Consequences of not adopting GDPR

body:
The world we live in today is vastly different from that of 1995 when data protection laws in the European Union were last updated (1998 in the case of the Data Protection Act in the UK). The GDPR is a new regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency. 

On the 25th May 2018, existing data protection regulations in the European Union will be replaced by the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

The GDPR provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member countries allowing a greater freedom of movement of individual's personal data.
displayTitle: What is GDPR and why is it needed?
title: What is GDPR and why is it needed?

body:
This lesson provides an overview of the General Data Project Regulation (GDPR) and the key differences from the existing Data Protection regulations. By the end of the lesson you should able to work more confidently with the requirements of GDPR and take a number of next steps.

The lesson explores:

  • What is GDPR and why is it needed?
  • What is the scope of GDPR?
  • Organisation obligations
  • Individuals rights
  • GDPR and privacy notices
  • Practical steps
displayTitle: Introduction to the General Data Protection Regulation
title: Introduction to the General Data Protection Regulation

body:
Privacy notices are one of the most visible aspects of GDPR adoption. 

Individuals must be informed clearly about what data is collected, exactly what it is used for and how they can exercise their rights over the data. This information must be presented to the individual as near to the point of data collection as possible. 

The privacy notice should clearly outline:

  1. Purpose of the processing and the legal basis for the processing
  2. The contact details of the controller and where applicable, the controller’s representative) and the data protection officer
  3. Details of transfers to third country and safeguards
  4. Retention period or criteria used to determine the retention period
  5. The data subject’s rights
  6. The existence of automated decision making, including profiling and information about how decisions are made, the significance and the consequences.

In addition to fines being imposed for non-compliance, they can also be imposed where a privacy notice is deemed unclear or misleading.
title: Privacy notices

body:
GDPR is first and foremost about guaranteeing strong data protection principles for individuals.

However, it shouldn’t just be seen as a matter of compliance. Adherence to GDPR also offers many opportunities for the public sector such as strengthening relationships with citizens and enhance service provision.

In this lesson we’ll explore the following:

  • Why GDPR is an opportunity, not simply a compliance exercise
  • Citizens’ trust and understanding of how their data is used
  • Key opportunities offered by GDPR for the public sector
  • How to advocate for the opportunities of GDPR in your organisation
displayTitle: What opportunities does the General Data Protection Regulation present for the public sector?
title: What opportunities does the General Data Protection Regulation present for the public sector?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
Due to the nature of the wide range of services and enterprises the public sector encompasses, there is a natural requirement to hold and share a huge amount of personal data

Whilst the public sector is subject to some exemptions from the regulation (for example, the right to be forgotten does not apply to the public sector if it impedes the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of health), GDPR remains a big shake-up, and will cause significant disruption to how public sector organisations store, manage and process personal data.

However, whilst it is certainly a challenge to overcome, it should also be treated as an opportunity to be embraced, as it makes public sector organisations more citizen-centric and positively enhances service provision. 

In fact, by securing this data advantage, many public sector organisations may come to regard the effects of the GDPR as benign – or even as positive.
title: Beyond compliance

body: Citizens currently have low levels of both trust and understanding about how their data is stored and used by organisations. It is important to address both of these issues when looking at GDPR as an opportunity.
displayTitle: Do citizens trust and understand how their data is stored and used?
title: Do citizens trust and understand how their data is stored and used?

_items.title: Low Trust
_items.body: Research from the ICO, the UK's independent body set up to uphold information rights., found that only 20% of the UK public have trust and confidence in companies and organisations storing their personal information.

_items.title: Low Understanding
_items.body: British adults are broadly unfamiliar with the specifics of how their personal data is being used by companies and organisations in the UK, with only 10% saying they have a good understanding of how their personal data is used, according to research by the ICO.

body: GDPR offers five key opportunities for the public sector. The regulation will provides the opportunity to...
title: Key opportunities of GDPR
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Strengthen relationships with citizens
_items.body: Managing consent allows providers to have more relevant, insightful conversations with citizens. It also allows service providers to offer their citizens more individual, tailored offerings.

_items.title: Enhance service provision
_items.body: GDPR gives public sector organisations the opportunity to explore how to provide new and improved services that meet citizens’ needs.

_items.title: Improve operational efficiency
_items.body: GDPR emphasises ‘data minimisation’ and stimulates an approach that emphasises thinking critically about what data is needed to provide a quality service. With a backbone of ‘privacy by design’, greater value is placed on the quality of insight rather than the quantity of data.

_items.title: Clearing the backlog
_items.body: GDPR is an opportunity for public sector organisations to ‘clear the backlog’ and separate valuable data from out of date or junk information. It is an opportunity to spring clean databases making it easier to hold quality over unnecessary quantity data.

_items.title: Build trust in the public sector
_items.body: GDPR provides the necessary impetus to clearly demonstrate how citizens’ personal data is handled, removing any underlying weeds of mistrust that have bedded themselves in through lack of transparency.

body: Moving GDPR beyond an issue of compliance towards embracing the regulation’s opportunities often requires a change in culture. The key to shifting perceptions is clear: effective communication from advocates within an organisation. Below we investigate three ways to position GDPR as an opportunity (rather than a compliance issue) in your public sector organisation.
displayTitle: Promoting the opportunities of GDPR in your organisation
title: Promoting the opportunities of GDPR in your organisation

_items.title: Develop an ‘Elevator Pitch’ for the opportunities of GDPR
_items.body:
Creating an effective pitch requires four elements:

  1. What it is - The problem GDPR can solve (e.g. low trust)
  2. What it can do – a tailored description of the benefit  (e.g. separate valuable data from out of date data; strengthen relationships with citizens)
  3. Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point or case study
  4. What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

When brought together, these create a clear, compelling case for action that can be used when seeking management approval, budgetary and resource support and downstream use and reuse. The pitch should be delivered in 90 seconds or less.

_items.title: Avoid words like ‘compliance’ and ‘infringement’
_items.body:
Stakeholders don’t engage with such language, which just leads people into a box-ticking exercise, a behaviour you don’t want to encourage

It’s important to package change (which is underpinned by compliance) in a more relatable way, so that all stakeholders understand the imperative of change to ensure necessary measures are in place.

_items.title: Apply a framework of privacy by design
_items.body:
Privacy by design (an approach mandated under GDPR) provides a useful manifesto for driving cultural change. In essence, ‘Privacy by Design’ is a framework which encourages treating personal data as you’d expect your own personal data to be treated

To apply a doctrine of privacy by design, a set of core questions to test yourself against can provide consistent framework for use across the business. These questions could include, but are not limited to:

  • What personal data am I holding?
  • Why do I hold this data? For which processing activities?
  • Do I need this data set? Can I achieve the same result with less data?
  • Do I have explicit consent? Will the customer have any objections?

title: Summary

body:
GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner.

There are 6 lawful basis outlined in GDPR at at least one must apply; without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process the personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting the personal data then the lawful basis does not apply.
title: Establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data

_items.title: Consent
_items.body:
Under GDPR the consent can only be gained in order to use data for a specific purpose.

Gaining consent must be through clear affirmative action, such as a button press or an opt-in tick box. Hidden conditions and opt-out options where no action is required does not constitute clearly obtained consent under GDPR.

Additionally the individual must be able to withdraw his or her consent at any time and the process for withdrawing consent must be as easy as that for giving consent.

_items.title: Performance of contract
_items.body:
The processing is necessary for a contract you have with the individual, or because they have asked you to take specific steps before entering into a contract.

For example in the obtaining of a quote for fitting double glazing on a house and the subsequent fitting.

_items.title: Legal obligation
_items.body:
The processing is necessary for you to comply with the law (not including contractual obligations).

For example an employer needs to process personal data to comply with employment law. In financial services personal data can be legally processed in order to help detect fraud. 

If you are processing on the basis of legal obligation, the individual has no right to data portability, or right to object. 

This individual has a right to erasure if the legal basis has expired. For example if an individual left a company over 3 years ago then there is unlikely to be a legal obligation for the employee to keep hold of all of an individuals data (a very small quantity is required for longer).

_items.title: Vital interests
_items.body:
The processing is necessary to protect someone’s life.

If you can reasonably protect the person’s vital interests in another less intrusive way, this basis will not apply.

You cannot rely on vital interests for health data or other special category data if the individual is capable of giving consent.

_items.title: Public task
_items.body:
The processing is necessary for you to perform a task in the public interest or for your official functions, and the task or function has a clear basis in law.

Generally this only applies to an organisation who are exercising official authority or carrying out a specific task in the public interest. 

For example, private water companies are likely to be able to rely on the public task basis even if they do not fall within the definition of a public authority.

_items.title: Legitimate interests
_items.body:
Legitimate interests is the most flexible lawful basis for processing, but you cannot assume it will always be the most appropriate.

If you choose to rely on legitimate interests, you take on extra responsibility for ensuring people’s rights and interests are fully considered and protected. You may need to carry out a balancing test that looks at if the individual’s interests override the legitimate interest.

Legitimate interests is most likely to be an appropriate basis where you use data in ways that people would reasonably expect and that have a minimal privacy impact. Where there is an impact on individuals, it may still apply if you can show there is an even more compelling benefit to the processing and the impact is justified. For example, if a customer could be offered a cheaper or better version of a product, then direct marketing may well be of legitimate interest to that individual.

_items.title: Data protection officers
_items.body:
The GDPR requires the appointment a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority, or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data. 

DPOs assist you to monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on your data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.

The DPO must be independent, an expert in data protection, adequately resourced, and report to the highest management level.

_items.title: Data breaches
_items.body:
GDPR introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

A personal data breach means a breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data. This includes breaches that are the result of both accidental and deliberate causes.

You should ensure you have robust breach detection, investigation and internal reporting procedures in place. This will facilitate decision-making about whether or not you need to notify the relevant supervisory authority and the affected individuals.

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to “result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals”

You must do this within 72 hours of becoming aware of the breach. 

You must inform those individuals without undue delay.

You must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether you are required to notify.

_items.title: Code of conduct
_items.body:
The GDPR endorses the use of approved codes of conduct and certification mechanisms to demonstrate compliance.

Governments and regulators can encourage the drawing up of codes of conduct. Codes of conduct may be created by trade associations or representative bodies.

Adhering to codes of conduct and certification schemes brings a number of benefits over and above demonstrating that you comply. It can:

  • improve transparency and accountability.
  • provide mitigation against enforcement action.
  • improve standards by establishing best practice.

body: The practical steps below will help ensure compliance with GDPR.
title: Practical steps

_items.title: 1. Establish scope
_items.body:
Where and when do you handle personal data?

What types of personal data do you handle?

Who do you share that data with, inside or outside EU?

Are you a controller, processor or both?

_items.title: 2. Establish lawful basis
_items.body: For each processing activity, what is the lawful basis that justifies the collection, storage and processing of each item of personal data?

_items.title: 3. Check your data lifecycle
_items.body:
Is privacy by design core to all your data processing activities involving personal data?

Have you carried out a Data Protection Impact Assessment where necessary?

Do you have appropriate contracts with data processors to ensure compliance?

Are your processes documented?

Do you have a tightly controlled data retention and deletion policy relating to the personal data?

_items.title: 4. Is the organisation ready to support GDPR?
_items.body:
Do you have/need to appoint a data protection officer?

Do you have procedures to rapidly identify and respond to data breaches?

Does your sector have/need a code of conduct to help with GDPR compliance?

_items.title: 5. Supporting individuals rights
_items.body:
Do you have a clear privacy notice that informs individuals about the use and rights over their data?

Do you have processes that support an individuals rights?

body:
There are two different types of personal data that are in scope of GDPR.

1. Personal data - Any data relating to an identified or identifiable person. 

2. Special categories of personal data - Particular categories of data that could create more significant risks to a person's fundamental rights and freedoms.
title: Personal data
instruction: Explore each of these in more detail below.

_items.title: Personal data
_items.body:
According to GDPR "personal data" means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. 

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

However not all data might be personally identifiable. For example the name John Smith is very common, however when combined with other data, such as date of birth and address this then becomes identifiable. Remember that names are not needed to identify someone, you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them.

_items.title: Special categories of personal data
_items.body:
Special categories of personal data (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) relates to how a person chooses to live their life or has to due to medical conditions. These categories of data could create more significant risks to a person's fundamental rights and freedoms and thus require greater levels of protection.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data (New in GDPR)
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation
  • Information about criminal convictions

Information about criminal convictions is still considered special however it is now covered by legislation that is separate from GDPR as outlined in the following section.

_items.title: Criminal convictions data
_items.body:
Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures can only be carried out:

  1. Under the control of official authority.
  2. When the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.

Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions shall be kept only under the control of official authority.

_items.title: Child data
_items.body:
Where the individual is below the age of 16 years, consent is required from the authorised by the holder of parental responsibility over the child.

Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years.

body:
GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required).
  2. The monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the Union.

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the EU that the GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those residing within the EU.
title: Territorial scope

body: GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully and communicate this basis clearly with the individual.
title: GDPR and privacy notices

body:
GDPR replaces the existing data protection relations throughout Europe (including the Data Protection Act 1998). The GDPR is a new regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency. 

The GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

Significant penalties and orders can be imposed on organisations who breach the GDPR, including fines of up to 20 million euros or 4% of a company’s turnover (whichever is larger).

One of main changes to GDPR Is the addition of a number of individuals rights. These rights are particularly relevant if the legal basis for processing personal data is either through consent or contract.

GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully and communicate this basis clearly. This is done through an organisations privacy notice; the most visible part of GDPR.

For more detail on GDPR beyond that covered here we recommend the dedicated EU GDPR website. The most important aspects of chapters 1-4 have been covered in this lesson.
title: Summary

body:
There are two main roles that organisations play in the processing of personal data. 

Controller

A controller is any body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.

Processor

A processor is any body which processes personal data in behalf of the controller.
title: Organisational roles

body: One of main changes to GDPR Is the addition of a number of individuals rights. These rights are particularly relevant if the legal basis for processing personal data is either through consent or contract (see the next section).
title: Individuals rights

_items.title: Right to be informed
_items.body:
Individuals have the right to be informed about the collection and use of their personal data. This is a key transparency requirement under the GDPR.

This information should be presented to the individual at point of collection in clear, concise language and be easily accessible. 

Such information should be presented in the privacy notice. You can read more in the later dedicated section on what must be contained within the privacy notice.

_items.title: Right to access
_items.body:
GDPR give rights of access to individuals to obtain from the data controller confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, where and for what purpose.

While rights to access are present in the Data Protection Act (DPA), GDPR makes the right to access for individuals free.

Further, the controller shall provide a copy of the personal data in an electronic format.

_items.title: Right to be forgotten
_items.body:
The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles the data subject (where conditions permit) to have the data controller erase personal data concerning him or her, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially have third parties halt processing of the data.

The conditions for erasure include the data no longer being relevant to original purposes for processing, no lawful basis existing for the data to be held and processed, or a data subject withdrawing consent (for example, by unsubscribing from all mailing lists).

_items.title: Right to rectification
_items.body:
Individuals are entitled to have personal data rectified if it is inaccurate or incomplete.

Where necessary, controllers must also rectify any copies shared with others and the process should take no more than 2 months.

_items.title: Right to restrict processing
_items.body:
Individuals have a right to ‘block’ or suppress processing of personal data.

Such rights can be exercised when:

  1. The accuracy of the personal data is contested.
  2. Where the individual has objected to the processing (only in the case of performance of a public task or legitimate interest).
  3. The processing is unlawful.
  4. The data is no longer required.

_items.title: Right to data portability
_items.body: GDPR introduces data portability - the right for a data subject to receive the personal data they have provided to the controller. This must be provided in a 'commonly used and machine readable format'. Additionally the individual has the right to transmit that data to another controller.

_items.title: Right to withdraw consent (if applicable)
_items.body:
If the lawful basis for processing is based upon obtaining consent, then the individual has the right to withdraw consent at any time. 

The process of withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving consent in the first place.

_items.title: Right to object
_items.body:
The right to object is not an absolute right and it applies only in certain circumstances:

  1. When the processing of data falls in the category of direct marketing. In this case the right is absolute as a data subject can object at any time.
  2. When data is used for research or statistical purposes. This time, objecting is not an absolute right as it can be overridden if the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest.
  3. The data is processed based on public or legitimate interests. In this case, the controller will need to demonstrate it has compelling legitimate interest to process the data that override the data subject’s rights and freedoms.

_items.title: Right to not be subject to solely automated decision making
_items.body:
Individuals have the right to not be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling.

Processing can be carried out if the decision is:

  • necessary for the entry into or performance of a contract
  • authorised in law
  • based on the individual’s explicit consent

In all cases individuals must be informed about the processing and be able to request human intervention or challenge a decision.

body:
For example, if Company A sells products to consumers and uses a company like MailChimp to email consumers on their behalf and track their engagement activity, then Company A is the data controller, and MailChimp is the data processor.

Generally speaking, the GDPR treats the controller as the principal party responsible for the ensuring compliance with GDPR. Thus in turn controllers should only choose processors who provide sufficient guarantees that meet the requirements of GDPR.
title: Component title

body: Protection of personal data is critical during every stage of the data lifecycle. GDPR also puts a number of key requirements on each stage.
title: GDPR and the data lifecycle

_items.title: 1. Create: Privacy by design
_items.body:
Privacy by design is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider individuals privacy from the start of the design of any system or service and not just bolted on at the end.

Where data processing is likely to result in high risk to individuals, GDPR makes a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) a legal requirement of this design process.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing;
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures;
  • identify and assess risks to individuals; and
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks.

_items.title: 2: Store: Contracts with data processors
_items.body:
It is highly likely that a controller will use a number of processors to not just store but also collect and analyse data.

Whenever a controller uses a processor it needs to have a written contract in place.

Controllers are liable for their compliance with the GDPR and must only appoint processors who can provide ‘sufficient guarantees’ that the requirements of the GDPR will be met and the rights of data subjects protected.

Processors must only act on the documented instructions of a controller. They will however have some direct responsibilities under the GDPR, such as notification of data breach, and be subject to fines or other sanctions if they don’t comply.

_items.title: 3. Use: Records of processing
_items.body:
The GDPR contains explicit provisions about documenting your processing activities (what you do with the personal data). 

Documenting your processing activities is important, not only because it is itself a legal requirement, but also because it can support good data governance and help you demonstrate your compliance with other aspects of the GDPR.

The amount documentation required varies depending on the size of your organisation and the activities carried out. 

Documentation can help in many areas including:

  • Establishing the extent of personal data your organisation holds
  • Establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
  • Writing of clearer privacy statements
  • Fulfilling your obligations to share the data with others including data subjects
  • Records keeping including data locations (territorial), records of consent and Data Protection Impact Assessment reports.

_items.title: 4. Share: Ensuring transfers are legitimate
_items.body:
The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data withing the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • To locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded.
  • To organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses. 
  • With the individual's informed consent.
  • Where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis.

_items.title: 5. Archive: Data retention and security
_items.body:
The GDPR requires personal data to be processed in a manner that ensures its security. This includes protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

Additionally GDPR requires that personal data only be retained while there is a lawful basis for doing so, such as proof of contract or employment. To do this is might not be necessary to keep the complete record, rather only a part. This is a practice known as data minimisation that can also help minimise risk (see next section).

_items.title: 6. Destroy: Data minimisation
_items.body:
The practice of data minimisation is about limiting personal data collection, storage, and usage to only the data that is relevant, adequate, and absolutely necessary for carrying out the purpose for which the data is processed.

The same is true of the retention of personal data; if any aspect of the data is no longer required to fulfil a lawful basis then it should be destroyed.

body:
Controllers are liable for their compliance with the GDPR and must only appoint processors who can provide ‘sufficient guarantees’ that the requirements of the GDPR will be met and the rights of data subjects protected.

Processors must only act on the documented instructions of a controller and shall not engage another processor without prior specific or general written authorisation of the controller. This said, processors are still required to comply with the law and contest any instruction from the controller that may result in illegal processing.

The processor must also fully comply with controllers instructions to delete or return all personal data to the controller at the end of the contract.

body: Which individuals of people does the GDPR apply to?
title: The scope of GDPR

_items.text: All EU citizens
All individuals interacting with an organisation operating in the EU, regardless of nationality
All EU citizens interacting with any company worldwide

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required).
  2. The monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the Union.

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the EU that the GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those located within the EU.

On this basis you do not need to be an EU citizen for the GDPR to apply. Anyone located in the EU interacting with services offered in the EU is in scope of the GDPR.

body: Which of the following are legal requirements under the GDPR?
title: Obligations for data controllers

Privacy by design (rather than addition)
Encryption of personal data
Hiring a data protection officer

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Privacy by design is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider individuals privacy from the start of the design of any system or service and not just bolted on at the end. 

GDPR also introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

The GDPR requires the appointment a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority, or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data.

The GDPR requires personal data to be processed in a manner that ensures its security. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used. Nothing specific about encryption is mentioned with the GDPR.

The GDPR give rights of access to individuals to obtain from the data controller confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, where and for what purpose.

While rights to access are present in the Data Protection Act (DPA), GDPR makes the right to access for individuals free.

Further, the controller shall provide a copy of the personal data in an electronic format.

body: Which countries can an individual’s personal data be transferred to (without needing to gain consent and it is not necessary in order to fulfil the legal basis)?
title: International transfers

_items.text: Any EU country
Any EU country or third country approved by the EU as being GDPR compliant
Any country

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • To locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded.
  • To organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses. 
  • With the individual's informed consent.
  • Where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis.
